A simple test for testing whether your 3D printer can print parts to fit. 2013-05-07: I have my TOM well calibrated already. Pair#0 always fits now. See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:52946 .

2013-05-07: I have my TOM well calibrated already. Pair#0 always fits now. See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:52946 . //////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////// My Makerbot is having problem to print parts to fit. I'm wondering whether I am the only one having such problem. So, I designed a simple test to test it. In this page, there is a .stl file test.stl. test.stl has six pairs of plug and slot. The pairs are labeled with number 0 to 5 with decreasing tolerance. Pair#0 is the ideal case where its plug and its slot are edge to edge touching each other. If you printed Pair#0 and its a tight fit, your 3D printer is perfectly calibrated. With respect to the ideal case, Pair#1 has a plug radius 0.05mm smaller and a slot radius 0.05mm bigger, Pair#2~0.10mm, Pair#3~0.15mm, etc... Please do me a favour. Print test.stl and reply to this page which pair is the first tight fit. The calibration of my Makerbot is probably way off, the first tight fit is Pair#2. Thanks a lot. PS: the six pairs for testing are also available individually, i.e. test00.stl to test05.stl. If you want to save some material, you may want to use them instead. All pairs are drew with Google Sketchup, and the source file is test.skp.

comments.text: Printed #5 and #2. First one's ok but the second doesn't fit. Not sure about the exact diameters but the #5 plug is 7.18 - 7.33 mm, the hole is 7.53 - 7.63 mm. .The #2 plug is 7.44 - 7.58 mm, the hole is 7.22 - 7.27 mm. All pieces have an outer diameter between 14.84 and 14.96 mm. Can't really say if it's the inner or outer (or both) diameters being off. Could you please post the exact measurements from where the offsets originate, please?

comments.text: The diff on the plug/hole diameters are due to the little bump where extrusion starts on the outer/innermost perimeter.

Correct me if I'm wrong, but this is the largest upload in Thingiverse history!
882 files @ 10.4 GB uncompressed! Includes 212 individual PEOPLE and all the source files for your learning pleasure. I present to you citizens of Thingiverse, PEOPLE! 212 individuals to be exact! This thing represents a vast majority of all the people I have 3D scanned. The scanning software I use is called Reconstructme which uses an XBox 360 Kinect as the scanner. Every person I scanned was 3D printed on site in a matter of minutes using my MakerBot Thing-O-Matic or Replicator. How was I able to obtain so many scans of PEOPLE?
Throughout the year I have been invited by various galleries, exhibitions and institutions to show off MakerBots and demo/display my scanning work. Scanning and printing PEOPLE gives them an intimate look into 3D printing and provides a basis for their understanding of all the possibilities.

Featured Events:
Chicago Ideas Week @ Oriental Theater, Chicago
EXPO Chicago 2012 @ Navy Pier, Chicago
Facemask exhibition @ Zhou B Art Center, Chicago
Improbable Objects exhibition @ What It Is gallery, Chicago
Maker Faire Detroit @ Henry Ford Museum, Detroit

1) scale (if you want)
2) slice
I typically slice at .4 infill, 1 shell. Print speed is usually at 150mm/s on my TOM and 180mm/s on my Replicator WHILE USING SAILFISH FIRMWARE!
3) print
4) MAKE ALL THE PEOPLE!

a box

My oven is old.  Made by Sears some time in the 1950's we think.  One of the knobs that controls the light and fan is missing and the other is melted.  I can't find replacement parts that fit.  So I decided to print them.

This was designed to print on a MakerBot.  I sliced and printed using ReplicatorG 0017 and only made a few tweaks specific to the bot I was using - nothing too drastic.  The spindle hole comes out a little undersized.  I'm not sure if that's something that can be tweaked in Skeinforge but you may need to enlarge the hole a bit.

description.text: Just didn't have the personal time to complete this project sorry :/ but at least a Rancor came out of it :)

How to Print:
Parts: Print as you wish, as a whole plate or in pieces, or in sections - all files are included.
Infill: 10% infill on all parts except the arms I suggest at 30% to support the underneath of the balljoint. The hands and forearms need to be sturdy.
Shells: No more than 2, if you do you will need to slightly sand the balls to get them to fit in the joints. this is designed with a high tolerance to print at 0.2mm or below.

title: Makerbot 'M' logo spool holder (for skinny hole + wider spools)

description.text: Makerbot spool holder for fatter/wider spools with skinnier 30-32mm centre holes and 90-100mm wide using the makerbot logo (why not? Complexity is free.. right?). Didn't really base it on any of the existing spools - so I hope this is an original contribution. I used the face off the logo from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4390 and the rest was via measuring up the normal spool and a bit of modification to make it strong enough via printing.

I would flip it so it is lengthways on the bed and use raft+supports - add some extra in-fill from the default (as it is a structural part after all) - maybe 25 - 30%+. 
I designed it for the filament from bilbyCNC.com.au that has approx 30mm holes and is approx 90mm wide.
Printed one - seems sturdy enough - pretty happy. Need to crank up the size of the "bumps" I put to stop the spool from sliding off as they're under the curve of the spool hole. Doesn't matter however as they're not necessary with the built in spacer at the end to keep the spool clear.

author: Slymanus

description.text:
Ever have your Arduino connected to your computer, forget it's connected and then run off to test something when all of a sudden, the cord / Arduino is yanked off the table, everything drags on the floor and if you're lucky, nothing is broken?
Well this connector allows you prevent all that headache by using your USB Cable as the mount your Arduino. It should be universal for both PC and Mac as opposed to a laptop screen clip or something

This widget was designed to be used with a Type A / B USB cable that has a housing type A/B housing with dimensions:
Type A: 16mm x 8mm
Type B: 12mm x 10mm
1) Download the widget.
2) It is recommended to print with the large cavity facing upwards
Notes:
1) The slots are added in each hole to allow for some play and snug fits for both USB connectors. Connecting the Arduino to the cable secures everything and once all is connected, your Arduino will be securely connected to your computer!
2) The stress relief holes don't 3D print well because the Skeinforge algorithm creates a couple floating island slices. This isn't a huge deal and when I have more time, I'll update with a better, more perfectly printable STL file soon.
Here's a YouTube setup video:
(in progress)
Cheers
Enjoy!

title: FPV Googles for Oakley O-Frame V1

description.text:
This are my first self-made FPV googles! While i'm still waiting for the Fatshark Dominator HD's to release i've build my own FPV googles. They are attached on a Oakley O-Frame MX google. Inside is a 4.3 inch LCD which i bought from ebay (car backup camera)
The size of the display is 122x72x15mm For the magnifying effect iv'e build a adjustable fresnel lens frame.
To adjust the distance of the lens you can turn on the two knobs.
The size of the lens i used is 135x95mm (http://www.3dlens.com/shop/pocket-fresnel-magnifier.php) The picture quality is in my opinion pretty good! :-) Parts used: 1 LCD car backup display -> Ebay
1 Fresnel lens -> http://www.3dlens.com
2 M4x45mm Hex Head bolts
2 M4 self locking nuts
2 M4 nuts
12 M3X8 (6-10mm possible) self tapping screws
1 MX google like Oakley O-Frame or similar
1 UHU super glue

Just print it :-)  
Maybe you have to scale it x10. My .stl files from Inventor turned out to be 1/10. Sorry about that.

description.text: The 2014 Zheng3 Garage Organization drive stampedes forward with this set of PVC pipe hangers. I'm using these to safely store a few of the lovely and talented Mrs. Zheng3's coir baskets until she can transfer them, or, perhaps just as likely, cause them to be moved by some other agent, almost certainly me because our children are both lazy and short, onto their summer stations on the veranda. These hangers are designed to fit a 5/8" (16mm) PVC pipe and have a hole and countersink for a drywall screw. Everything's Better With Drywall Screws. Includes a capped end and an open internal hanger. Scaling to fit other diameters of PVC is left as an exercise for the reader. Installation under heavy load or in areas prone to pronounced seismic activity is not recommended.

title: FIFA World Cup Trophy
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Goooooool! Whether your team wins or loses, you can still have a trophy! This is based upon Martin Le Roy\'s sweet model: http://sketchup.google.com/3dwarehouse/details?mid=7134e227c856685d50f3a2fc91e9b3c5 Quite a bit of work with netFabb was necessary to make the model skeinforge-able. The anthem gcode files came from http://simplythebest.net/sounds/Midi/miscellaneous_midis.html and were processed into gcode using mid2cnc http://github.com/TeamTeamUSA/mid2cnc. Your country anthem not here? More anthem MIDI files are here: http://www.mayasite.net/MIDI/Atlas/worldlst.html

Printing
  • Download fifa_world_cup_trophy.stl
  • Create gcode file of fifa_world_cup_trophy.stl using skeinforge
  • Load gcode file in ReplicatorG and click Build
  • Goooooool!
    • Finishing
    To make the trophy gold, either paint it with metallic paint or gild it using gold leaf. You might want to sand it to smooth out the surface before applying paint or leaf. Music
    This is a purely optional step and YMMV. Proceed at your own risk.
  • Download one of the anthem gcode files
  • Position Z-stage about 50mm above build platform
  • Load gcode file in ReplicatorG and click Build button
    • You should now hear the anthem as the Z-stage moves up and down. Now that you\'ve verified that the anthem will play on your Cupcake, add it to the end of your trophy gcode file for a patriotic end-of-print celebration.
  • Create gcode file of fifa_world_cup_trophy.stl using skeinforge
  • Open gcode file, append anthem gcode to end of file, and save
  • Load gcode file in ReplicatorG and click Build
    • At the end of the print the anthem will play!

title: Teaching Model of Da Vinci's Tank

description.text:
This was created for 7th Grade History students learning about Renaissance inventors.
Students first studied his images and were asked to comment on the feasibility of building and using this tank.
They were then put in teams of 4 and given a half-built model. They were asked to finish assembling it and then asked about feasibility and function again.
Initially most students thought it could be built and work but the physical model made them question design (he'd drawn the gearing wrong), size (in order to fit people and guns inside it would have to be huge and heavy), etc.
This model enabled a rich and engaging dialog about da Vinci and his ideas.
This is made using dowels and 5mm Purebond from Home Depot.

title: Axial SCX10 Battery Relocation Support V2

description.text:
This is my second version of the battery relocation support I've made. I realized that with V1 it was only possible to use it, when your battery packs have the exact same size as mine. So i made an other one. This part is designed to place the battery of your SCX10 over the front axle. It fits all SCX10 chassis. The first part fits over the bumper struts. The second part will replace the annoying supports of the RC box. It works with battery packs up to 150x50mm! I've provided two files for the plate, one is with openings for the cables of your battery. In case your cables coming out on the side and not on the top side. The other one is without. Update 25.05.2014:
Just added a 5mm longer front support and a 10 mm shorter back support. To tilt back the battery in case you are not using the original RC box. Thanks for the good input powermik! Please hit "like" if you like it :-)

Enlarge the two holes in the frame where the original RC box support was with a 3mm drill.  
Firmly press M3 nuts in the battery holder plate (in the provided hex holes)  
Maybe you have to scale it x10. My .stl files from Inventor turned out to be 1/10. Sorry about that.

comments.text: Would it be possible to get a version that allows for a frame mount steering servo, basically a mount that works on scx-10 2?
comments.author: Icanmakethat

comments.text:
Just made one, fits perfectly after sizing up 10x.
Instead of enlarging the hole i did cut a m3 thread.
Its a close fit for a 5000mah 2s lipo and the servo nearly has contact at full articulation - no height wasted.
Could you upload the source files? or provide a version that has a 5mm longer front support and a 10 mm shorter back support?
That way the battery can be tilted backwards if one does not mount the original electronics box

author: alexd41

description.text:
A teachable moment I print out and give to kids at my children's school.  I use them to explain 3D printing.  They hang them on their backpacks.  
Switching colors at about 33% and 80% complete can give the number, background and letter/border contrasting colors.  The "3" is thin enough that it is very translucent when held up to the light.  (My son was running the printer for this batch, and he likes red and yellow...)  
The tag is modeled with a brim to prevent lifting.  When I print multiples, I overlap the brims to reduce the number of edges that could lift.
this is a slide-on battery cover for a 6 inch Carrera Precision Digital Caliper.
I printed this on a Makerbot Replicator in PLA, 20% infill, 0.20mm layer height, 1 shell, 210 degree extruder, unheated platform, at a speed of 40.

comments.text: What slicer did you use and how many shells? 3 possible problems... 1 - printer has never been calibrated since purchase (rookies). 2 - slicer is incorrect, some slicers like Miracle Grue vs. Slic3r, make different size things. Slic3r is accurate because of the algorythems used to make the shells. If you shell thickness exceeds the thickness of them model, slicer compensates for it. Others don't, and will make it too wide or not wide enough. 3 - You are using a broken model (like this one) generally from someone who didn't go to school to learn this. Use Netfabb cloud before you print. If you still have trouble, come email-message me and ill share some guru tricks.

title: An Open Invitation to Design Join

description.text:
We want you, and you, and you, to collaborate. 
â€œAn Open Invitation to Designâ€ is a design-led research project that explores the areas of collaboration, authorship and derivative design, associated with digital fabrication technologies and communication networks in the context of furniture design. It specifically serves as a critique of the open design process and aims to demonstrates the design potential of using open source methods as a generative element to design innovation.
The idea is to collaboratively design multiple chairs, building off someone else's contribution. All that is required to participate is a digital file, that is then uploaded and through Thingiverse made a derivative of this thing. 
The collaborative chairs will then be produced at the FabLab in New Zealand, and documented in a Masters Thesis on Open Design. Credit will be given to the respective authors.

So how does it work The chair is split into 3 parts, legs, seat and back rest. I imagine at first there will be a range of odd chair parts, hopefully over time people will take these parts and build from them with the goal of having a finished chair with 3 parts designed by 3 different people. Every part designed only needs to meet two criteria. One it must be manufacturable on one of the machines listed below. Shopbot CNC Laser Cutter (Sheet metal) UP 3D printer, PLA and ABS bed size of 140mm L x 140mm W x 135mm H Laser Cutter (Sheet acrylic) Two it needs to incorporate the standardized join that can be found in the attached files. This is to enable parts to be built upon with relative ease. The join comes in 3 variations. All use 10mm diamater hole of any depth and are surround by a required flat section (In grey) When you upload your part please feel free to leave build instructions and what inspired you. If you are building off someone else's part please let me know what part it is. As long as your part meets these requirements you are free to make what you want and I will do my best to produce it. This all may seem a little confusing, so please ask if you have any questions. Here is a file to get the ball rolling. www.thingiverse.com/thing:34078 Looking forward to seeing what you create. A big thank you in advance.

comments.text:
design-led? So you are designing for the purpose of designing?
That is weird, or what is normally called art. Design is intended to fulfil acute and/or latent user needs. What you are looking for is not design (as there are no user needs apart from 'a chair') but individual self-expression (you are free to make anything what you want), which is art. You are not planning for prototypes, that also points to art not design. And lastly: "it [...]serves as a critique[...]": yes, art again.

description.text: A zelda object. Designed in Sketchup by Scott L., a grade 11 student.

We weren't sure if we could get away with "no support".  Our bridging is okay but the biggest gap is slightly over 1cm.
The one pictured was printed using ABS Plastic on a Replicator G with 2 shells, 220 degree print temperature, no support, and a 40% infill.
We also tried another print with 1 shell and 225 degree print temperature and it turned out to look approximately the same as the 2 shell lower temp. print.
We did have an issue with the bridge and a few filaments fell away, but after trimming them off it still looks pretty good overall.
Update: Tried a variant of the shape and printed using glow in the dark ABS with 15% infill, 1 shell and 225 degree print temperature.  See extra images.  This one solved the bridging problem.

author: formid

description.text:
A ring that can be inscribed with a message in binary around the outer band.  Very useful for "special" occasions. 
This design was used to print the engagement ring for my then-girlfriend, but now-fiance.  I can attest to the effectiveness of this design :)  Several revisions were printed in several plastics from Shapeways.  Frosted detail probably was the most impressive plastic version due to a slight transparency.  White strong and flexible worked, but did not reproduce the engravings well.  The silver print from Shapeways came out very well.

• Download the openscad file.
  • Change the "text1" and "text2" variables to match the message you wish to encode. I used http://www.roubaixinteractive.com/PlayGround/Binary_Conversion/Binary_To_Text.asp to perform the translation.
  • Render and print
  • Present for special occation.

comments.text: Congatulations to you both! You seem to have used the same design as I used for my FiancÃ©s ring (minus the binary message of course) putting me in the unfortunate position of having to tell someone that their custom made engagement ring isn't quite as unique as it was :p

title: Template for Arduino Uno Case, LCD 16x2, 9V Battery Holder, Encoder and place for an On/Off Switch

description.text:
Thanks to FreeCAD anyone can adapt this thing for his individual needs.  
A simple case for an Arduino Uno, with included place for an LCD display (16x2 chars) and 9V battery holder, places for an encoder and On/Off swich. The USB connector is open, the external power supply of the Arduino Uno is hidden.  
The 9V battery holder can easily be replaced by a holder for 4xAAA batteries which might provide longer power supply for the Arduino.  
I'm using this case for an Intervallometer based on the Arduino Uno for my RX100M2.

Just print the upper and lower part it should be pretty self-explaining.
Use 3mm screws!

description.text: Many of the laser pointers you can buy from amazon from china are going to contain an internal barrel shaped laser diode and small circuit board... like this one: http://www.amazon.com/Green-Laser-Pointer-Black-Casing/dp/B000P0SYPS/ref=sr_1_3?rps=1&ie=UTF8&qid=1352421078&sr=8-3&keywords=laser+pointer Once you liberate the internal electronics from the battery connecting tube, you may want a way to mount it to another substrate. This thing can help. I had already begun to build a laser kaleidoscope with several DC motor mounts, so it seemed like a good idea to reuse the design file from that and resize the cavity to 13mm to accomodate the laser. It worked great! I have included a slot at the top for a zip tie to cinch the two parts closer for a friction fit, but in reality the size was close enough to the diode that I was able to pry the two halves apart slightly, insert the diode, and it was clamped tightly automatically. update: I've since encountered alternative laser diodes with slightly larger diameters, so I'm including them here in case that's easier for you than to resize the file yourself. update 2: Cute overload!! I received a couple of laser diodes in the mail and they're only 6mm in diameter!!
Autodesk inventor fusion file included. Have you tried inventor fusion? It's pretty nice and it's free!

description.text:
I am making this for a possible upcoming Super Smash Bros. Tournament. I just got a 3D printer and thought I would try uploading something I created!  
I oriented the files in an optimal position for printing but you may have to play around with the orientation depending on the printer.  For best results print at least two pole pieces to make the trophy taller  
Each part is scale relative to one another, but depending on your printer you may have to adjust print size.
I sketched the "N" up in CREO Parametric along with the other components
torus with double 12 turn evolute paths, created with the liquidbuddha.studios cosmic geometry toolkit! (http://www.liquidbuddha.com/project-cosmic-geometry-toolkit/)

This "evolute" path model was created in Maya using the liquidbuddha.studios Cosmic Geometry VFX toolkit (open-sourced on GitHub).  An "evolute" (short for Evolutionary Wavefront) is an expression of toroidal geometry, which traverses the surface of a torus, defined by the number of "loops" or "turns" around the torus. With the Cosmic Geometry toolkit, you are able to create a torus of any height-ratio, any number of turns. A simple extrude of the path creates the printable geometry (also part of toolkit)  
This specific model is a combination of two mirrored 12-turn evolutes, creating a "double torus".  The dimensions are of a traditional "donut" style torus, with a height-ratio of about 0.5 or 1/2.

title: Prusa i3 combined J-Head/object cooling system for Gregs/Wade extruder (30 mm), iteration 5b

description.text:
Prusa i3 combined J-Head/object cooling system for Gregs/Wade extruder.
  • 3 fans of 30mm are needed
  • 12 screws M3 x 16 are needed
  • ABS is recommended
  • it is printable without need of support structures
    • The design is loosely based upon following thingiverse designs:
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:127932
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:190769 Improvements compared to the original design:
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:217126
  • efficiency of object cooling fan-inlets has been largely improved.
  • the blower ring, which is cooling the object, now has cylindrical tubes pointing at the nozzle tip of the J-Head.
  • the inlet of the J-Head cooling fan has been enlarged.
    • I did add the FreeCAD source files so that anyone can easily improve the current design.

author: projunk

description.text:
Connects a Gardena Microdrip 6mm hose to a 1/2" water outlet.  
This is part of a home brewed balcony watering system where inexpensive solenoid valves are to be used to control segments of the Gardena Microdrip watering system.

Printed on Mendel I3 Berlin, sliced using KISS Slicer with 0.4mm extrusion width, 0.2mm skin thickness, rough support and 10% straight infill. Needs some afterwork as cleaning the 3mm end nozzle with a 3mm drill and scraping off the support. The 1/2" internal thread should work "out of the box".

title: E3D Bowden mount for Rostock MAX - Laser cutter edition

description.text: Quick conversion for those that don't have a working printer (because it doesn't have a hot end mount) but have a working laser cutter for some reason.

Get laser. Cut material or materials of proper thickness.  
I had to use an unusually large kerf offset, which might be an issue with my lazy slicing. 0.25mm or so on my laser cutter instead of 0.14 typical.  
I used two different acrylic thickness to bring it up to the proper size. Mounted on my 3D printer with some M4 threaded rod and nylon compression tube fittings that I had kicking around. McMaster-Carr 50775K409, but I'm sure you can get something better if you're actually going to buy new hardware.

author: Jarrett

description.text: The wire channels on the original FlexBot quadcopter design create structural weak points (as I found out).  This design merely fills those channels in.
Should work just like the original.  I just wrap the wires once over the motor strut and plug them in.  This keeps them out of the way.
I needed a filament holder for my 3D printer.  The brackets are printed and then assembled with 1/2" PVC pipe and fittings.

Filament Holder Assembly Print out using ABS:
1 Axel Hub
4 Spoke Clamps Go down to the hardware store and get:
8 feet of 1/2â€ PVC pipe and the following 1/2" fittings
1 - Tee
2 - 90 Degree Elbows
6 â€“ 45 Degree Elbows
3 â€“ Caps (get 8 more Caps if you want them on the spoke ends)
1 â€“ small can of ABS / PVC all purpose cement
4 - 5mm by 20mm machine screws
4 â€“ 5mm nuts Filament support spoke assembly: Cut 4 lengths of PVC 1.5â€ long.
Cut 4 lengths of PVC 6â€ long. Glue the short and long pieces together with 4 of the 45 degree bends to make 4 spokes. Then glue the 4 spokes into the axel hub angled back so the filament will be positioned over the axel hub bearing region. Cut 4 lengths of PVC 4â€ long and glue into the Spoke Clamps. Put the screws and nuts through the clamps. I found that by putting a spacer between the clamp surfaces I could tighten the screw and draw the nut down into the socket. Slide the Spoke Clamp assemblies on to the spokes. Glue on the 8 PVC Caps if you chose this option. The caps might just be pressed in place so they could be removed later if desired. Cut 1 length of PVC 5.5â€ long for the axel. Glue a cap on one end, put it through the axel hub (with the cap on the end by the spokes) and glue a 45 degree elbow on the other end. Note: donâ€™t get glue between the axel hub and the PVC axel for obvious reasons. Base assembly: Cut 2 lengths of PVC 5â€ long
Cut 2 lengths of PVC 10â€ long Glue a PVC Cap on one end of the 10â€ lengths and a 90 degree elbow on the other end. Glue the 5â€ pieces into the other end of the 90 degree elbow. Cut 2 lengths of PVC 4â€ long Glue these 4â€ lengths into a 45 degree elbow. Glue this piece into the right angle part of the Tee (not the straight through section). Align it so the bend goes off at a right angle to the straight through Tee section. Glue the two 5â€ pieces into the straight through part of the Tee. Align the parts so the â€œfeetâ€ are flat on the floor and the part with the 45 angle is vertical. Glue the 45 degree elbow in the axel / hub assembly to the base. Align the axel parallel to the feet. Rotate two spoke clamps to drop on the filament coil. Rotate them back to hold the coil in place. Print with no tangles!!!!!

This is the largest possible print of Emmett's Screwless Heart Gears on a Replicator.  
Weighing in at over 800 grams and taking 50 hours to print, this will prove to your loved one you love them the Maximum amount possible!

Scale up the original parts 215% (except the pins, they have been pre-scaled). Use the modified screwless heart gear pins. Center and rotate the even numbered gears to fit on your build plate. Gears printed at 0.2mm layers, 10% infill, 2 shells. ABS at 120mm/s feed, 200mm/s travel - 230 degrees with Sailfish. I used 50% infill on the pins and 25% on the center piece. The pins have been modified slightly to fit easier and still retain a tight, smooth action. I still sand my pins and the holes of the center block with 300 - 600 grit sandpaper to make the gears turn as smoothly as possible. Sometimes I wipe them with acetone too. You can use the original pins scaled to match your print, but sanding will be required. Modified Screwless Heart Gear Pins @215%: https://tinkercad.com/things/6SoYQFaAM3Q

This is a silly take on the proteosome as a person.   
Proteasomes are protein complexes that degrade unneeded or damaged proteins by proteolysis, a chemical reaction that breaks peptide bonds.  
Taken from PDB id 1FNT removed the outer 19S regulatory particle of the proteosome to leave only the 20S core particle.

This is for beaders. You put your beads in the pot and spin it gently by twiddling the shaft. If you point a piece of beading wire into the pot at a shallow angle, it miraculously picks up beads far faster than you can thread them manually.
You can put a small bead under the cavity in the base to make it spin more easily.

description.text: This is my auger based pet feeder inspired by the work of Tunell and kitlaan here on Thingiverse.  The design centers on using a PVC plumbing tee and printed parts to build an auger screw conveyor that dispenses pet food.  The screw is driven by standard hobby servo which can be controlled by your favorite microcontroller. This means anything can control the pet feeder activation, a simple timer, a smart phone, twitter, your own brain waves or even better your pet's brain waves!

I have posted the complete build instructions on Instructables http://www.instructables.com/id/Pet-Feeder/ The pet feeder is design to work with a 2â€ PVC plumbing tee, a standard size servo modified for continuous rotation and is assembled using 4-40 machine screws and nuts. I used a plastic pitcher as a hopper which is attached with screws to the funnel, but any suitable replacement could be used. Two stands form the base of the feeder and could be cut from most sheet material on a cnc router or laser cutter. I have included the dxf file for the stands. Its up to you to decide how to control the activation on the feeder but I will note that servo cannot just be driven forward each time you would like to dispense pet food, this will result in jams and a stalled servo. I have found that a pattern of first rotating the screw 60degrees backward and then 120degrees forward clears kibble jams. Just repeat this sequence as needed to dispense the required amount of food. The parts were inspired by Tunell and kitlaan but I created my own models for everything with Solidworks. My Solidworks files are in the zipped folder which includes the assembly from the picture.

comments.text: I like the simplicity of this and agree to the openendedness of how it can be controlled. However not that it is crucial in this application but could you think of a simple way (without additional electronics) to seal off the reservoir of pet food when the system is not dispensing it? Wish I had this in person to take a look myself for a suitable way todo that. Great work.

• Print out the blade holder and box using whatever settings you want.

  • Cut off the small support on the blade holder tab.

  • Insert a micro blade into the holder by lifting the blade holder tab.

  • Insert the blade holder into the box.

  • Use your new tool to find out whats in the box!

The shawm is the loud medieval ancestor of the oboe. This shawm has a simple six-hole fingering system. I am particularly pleased by how this model turned out. The finger spacing is not too wide (32mm between holes), and it can play a solid octave and a half. The pitch is similar to soprano voice (tenor plus one octave). Thanks again to John Boshua for an excellent print in ABS plastic. Sample audio:
http://soundcloud.com/paul-francis-harrison/ja-nuns-hons-pris-shawm

Depending on the capabilities of your printer, print the instrument as a single object, or in two segments, or in four segments. I've provided STL files so that you can print the segments in a single run or separately. The shawm in the photos was printed from ABS plastic in two segments, with an 0.1mm layer size. Make a drinking-straw reed using the instructions here:
http://www.instructables.com/id/Practice-double-reed-from-a-drinking-straw/?ALLSTEPS The straw should be 4-5mm diameter. If the joints don't quite fit together, sand them a little until they do. Use some sort of grease to make tight seals between all the joints, and with the reed. The fingering chart is straightforward:
http://www.logarithmic.net/pfh-files/design/folk-shawm-fingering.pdf More sizes of shawm, and designs with a more complex fingering system similar to recorder, are available in the "pre-built" design pack downloadable from:
http://www.logarithmic.net/pfh/design

That Elon is one smart fella and his designs are cutting edge requiring the best from us Americans to finally get away from those dreaded antique Russian rocket engines America has relied on for so long. One of the things i love about Thingiverse (haha) is all the connectors, fasteners and hinges that people upload. My art making is loosely focused on modular work and systems. So for me Thingiverse is the perfect research environment. Currently i am building a collection of all the fasteners and connectors that catch my eye, for a new body of work i plan to produce in the New Year.
Recently I have been making a series of "Art History" PEZ toppers. I really like the juxtaposition of iconic sculpture / artworks on the candy dispenser. But i'm also pretty intrigued by the mechanical and formal qualities of this PEZ stem itself.
To further extend the modular possibilities for the PEZ dispenser i have hacked together a "Foot" connector, not dissimilar to Wallace's slippers in form if not pattern.
I modeled it in Tinkercad and you can find a lot of my files up there too. This is very much a work in progress. I don't think it's symmetrical for one thing. But it seems to work. I have tested several attachings and detachings.  
I have uploaded the basic "slipper" file. I have also attached this file to tbusers "Dispenser Insert" so that you can stack multiple PEZ on top of each other. I plan to make some customs with different heads and embedded connectors. 
I also plan to start making larger sculptures from multiple PEZ stems, connected together with 2 way and 4 way connectors. As these pieces develop i will add them to this page.

title: Bulldog Lite Extruder Prusa i3 Rework Mount

description.text:
This is a mount for the Bulldog Lite extruder for Prusa i3 Rework Edition. It is designed to mount to the standard i3 Rework X-carriage and use the existing fan shroud. As long as you are able to move your X end stop far enough left or relocate it to the right end of the axis it retains the full build area. This mount keeps the extruder parallel to the X-axis instead of perpendicular so that the weight of the stepper is as close to the bearing rods reducing X-carriage sag. I have left the original unused mounting holes on the mount for mounting additional fans, leveling attachments, lights etc.
.
06/10/14 Added a custom fan shroud for this mount for a 30mm fan and the Hexagon hot end, will also work with other similar sized hot ends *This will also mount the Bulldog XL extruder but you will loose some print area in the X axis due to the extra length from the gearbox.

50% Infill
3 Perimeters

title: gearCuffs
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
or gearLinks ...I can't decide which name I prefer.
Anyway, the story:
Talking to my mom she told me about how my dad couldn't keep his hands off the gEarings I made her for mother's day, and how everytime they went out, he wanted her to wear them so he could show them off to people.
So for Christmas (yes, I'm way behind on uploading this thing) I modified the design to make them a pair of cufflink gears. This involved making everything larger, widening the track for the posts, and closing the hole in the center that was used to store the earrings backings.

So here's the process. Using 1/4" thick material (I use african padauk craft board, because I love this wood.) 1) Cut the dowel jig. (The blue rectangle)
2) Without moving your material, place a 1/8" diameter, 13.75" long dowel in the jig.
3) Cut the red lines. (This will cut your dowel to length, add the notches, and then cut all the parts)
3a) I recommend breaking up your red line cuts, first the dowel notches, second the dowel cuts, and finally the rest of the pieces.
4) Etch the first etch layer. (The black lines & shapes) This will remove some of the material from the back of the cufflinks. (And if you leave the signature, sign the back of the case)
5) Etch the second etch layer, this will make the indents to which the cufflinks will be glued and placed.
6) Remove your parts from the laser.
7) Glue the cufflink blanks to the back of the cufflink gears.
8) Assemble the rest!

comments.text: Very cool stuff.  Where did you get the 1/8 "African Padaku Craftboard" as a quick google does not find anything on this.
comments.author: ril3y

comments.text:
Hi ril3y,
Sorry about that, there was a typo in my materials list, the wood I use is actually African Padauk. The thinnest out there seems to be 3/16", but I use 1/4" thick.
comments.author: ril3y

author: asp55

description.text:
"Every minute, at least one woman dies from complications related to pregnancy or childbirth"
-World Health Organization http://www.who.int/features/qa/12/en/index.html UPDATE 02012-12-15: Meeting went great; beginning collaboration with WinSenga team in 2013! First order of business is obtaining an antenatal care medical manikin/simulator. Anyone have one they want to donate? UPDATE 02012-12-04: Excited to meet the WinSenga team this week! They're in the US taking meetings and receiving their Microsoft Imagine Cup award. Inspired by the awesome work of the WinSenga team http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20120927-mobile-ear-for-pregnancy-problems, this is a MakerBottable Pinard horn http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pinard_horn, a 19th century fetal stethoscope. This MakerSenga - senga is the local Ugandan name for midwife - can be used to diagnose fetal health by a trained practitioner or, paired with the end cap microphone, by anyone with the WinSenga software! By Miles Lightwood of TeamTeamUSA. Community health worker photo by Sven Torfin

For a traditional Pinard horn, print:
  • MakerSenga.stl
    • For a potentially WinSenga http://winsenga.org compatible Pinard horn, print both files:
  • MakerSenga.stl
  • MakerSenga_cap.stl
    • Notes
  • You must use support material to print the MakerSenga_cap.stl, and it's not as difficult as it sounds! Use MakerWare's built-in raft and support if you've got a Replicator, or use Matt's excellent support settings for a T-O-M or a Cupcake: makerbot.com/blog/2011/06/27/makerbot-microtip-using-the-support-features-in-skeinforges-raft-tool/
  • Once printed, the support material is easily removed.
  • The cap doesn't rotate fully to a locking position yet (but can be sanded/filed to fit).
  • The exact microphone has yet to be determined, but the one pictured is the first candidate. The design will remain "in progress" until the final microphone is determined.
  • The pictured MakerSenga has not been tested with WinSenga and is a proof-of-concept only.
    • You can print it - you know you can!

comments.text: Printed one on Ultimaker. Seems no need for support material on Ultimaker. Will have to wait a couple of weeks before I'll hear my baby in my wifes belly ;-) Hope I'll b able to connect a phone to this soon. Cheers! remixed_from.author: art103
remixed_from.title: Bearing Spool Holder for UP! pp3dp

title: Bearing Spool Holder for Up! Mini pp3dp

description.text:
I found the bearing holder for the Up! pp3dp FDM system designed by art103 (bearings by chylld) to build on our Up! Mini system. However, the bracket to attach the bearing shaft to the machine is different on the original Up! machine.
This part allows the bearings designed by chylld/art103 to be used on the Up! Mini system.

Print 1x Up! Mini Spool Holder
Print 2x "Spool Holder bearing" by art103
I printed both with a layer thickness of 0.25 mm, with the highest fill setting and supports < 10 degree.
Put one of the bearings onto the shaft, flange towards the mounting plate, then add the spool and then the second bearing, flange outwards.
I tried originally printing my holder vertically, and this gave better profile on the shaft which didn't need further work. However, it was weak structurally and snapped where the shaft meets the mounting plate, when one of my colleagues bumped the system, pushing the spool into the wall.
Printing it horizontally leads to the shaft not being uniform, and requires sanding/filing to fit the bearings (as found by art103). However, the shaft should be stronger due to the lateral layers. I also printed it using the highest fill mode which should also help strengthen the component. I haven't tried printing it at an angle but this could work.
Once assembled, the spool now turns smoothly. :-)

comments.text: Hi Protonite. I found that the bearing stuck tightly around the shaft - in fact, the main issue was removing it! There wasn't an issue of the bearing turning on the shaft, as the shaft was quite rough.
comments.author: piphil

comments.text:
Looks really nice. To make it a bit stronger, i would suggest to make a hole from the plate-side thru the middle of the shaft (not all the way thru) so you could add a screw. Some simple M3x20 (or longer?) screw should be enough to take some of the force away that pushes from the inner bearing and make the shaft hold on to the plate. I'll start printing the bearings and then try to make a "remix" of your shaft/plate design with my idea added to it.
By the way: It the outer bearing holding on to the shaft, or is there a risk of the bearing slipping out of it? If there is, i would add a little groove to the shaft and use an U-Shaped clip that snaps on the shaft so it keeps everything in place.
comments.author: Protonite

Robust wetsuit hanger. No more moulded wooden hangers, no more broken plastic hangers. This wetsuit hanger was designed to withstand wet and heavy neoprene suits that need drying or storage.
Wide shoulders should prevent unnecessary material stretching.
Hook mount design should prevent pullout. This is easily printable with ABS on Replicator 2x using 0.3mm resolution, 2 shells and 30% infill. I have used HIPS supports for 'Neck' and 'Link' parts.
'Shoulders', 'Neck' and 'Hook wedge' need gluing before assembly. I have used acetone/ABS self made glue mix. Attempts to print 'Shoulder' parts with supports on R2x result in failed prints - some kind of positioning glitch secondary to size of the model (Makerware slicer). Bear in mind that this hanger (made with above settings) will use approx 365g of ABS material (about $11 filament cost) and will take just under 17h to print....

description.text:
This is a modification of Airtripper's Extruder for NEMA 17 stepper with a planetary gearbox (21 mm hole spacing)
2 tube attachment versions are available:
-- M4 nut
-- M5 Pneumatic push-fit adapter

I printed in PLA with a 0.5mm nozzle, 0.2mm layer height, 100% fill. You need:
-- 2x M3x6
-- 3x M3x25
-- 2x M3 nut
-- 2x M3 washer
-- 2x M3x45
-- 2x spring or piece of rubber diesel pipe (see Airtripper's original)
-- M4 nut or M5 pneumatic push-fit adapter Please note, this version doesn't use a support bearing yet - I didn't have a small enough bearing to fit the narrower hole spacing and 8mm gearbox shaft. I will upload a revision soon. Updated: added a version for M5 pneumatic push-fit adapter

title: 20x50x10 mm - 10 cubic centimetres volume calculation part

description.text:
This is a simple 50 x 20 x 10 mm block which is 10 cubic centimeters in volume. It makes it perfect for calibration and measuring plastic filament consumption.
In other words $/cm3.
By Creative Tools

  • Home - Things - GooglePlus - Twitter - Facebook - Youtube - Instructables - Instagram - Flickr - Vimeo - LinkedIn

• Make sure to measure the average diameter of your 3D printers filament
  • Adjust the 3D printers software according to the diamter
  • 3D print the object at 100% infill
  • Weigh the final result on an accurate scale
  • Divide the weight by ten
  • Now you have an accurate weight per 1 cubic centimeter which makes it possible to calculate the cost per cm3.

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:116042 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=116042
Spring loaded belt tensioner for Prusa Mendel.

Print two of each part.
The parts were made in SolidWorks so unfortunately I don't have any OpenScad files for them.
All STLs have been loaded into Netfabb and repaired to ensure they are perfectly manifold.
The vitamins you'll need for assembly are a 608zz bearing two extension springs and either an m3x20 screw or a 4-40 0.75" screw.  Rather than describing assembly it is probably easiest to just look at the picture.  Insert the screw through the base of one of the bearing holder arms and screw them together.

remixed_from.title: Makerbot 'M' logo spool holder (for skinny hole + wider spools)

description.text:
This spool holder was designed for use 25-30 core diameter x 100mm spools as found with typical 3rd-party PLA sources.  
The part is designed in two pieces, for easy print-ability w/o supports.  Once its complete just glue to together w/ CA glue.

• Print
  • (optional) insert alignment pins
  • Apply CA ("super") glue to one side
  • Clamp together until the glue cures<
  • Enjoy it.
    • Note: that STL file has 2.1 clearance holes for 2.0mm pins, but they printed smaller on my makerbot. Therefore I used 1.5mm spring pins. :)

title: Mist Spray Holder for Lego R2-D2 Robots & Other Things

description.text: WARNING: Misusing canned air can be dangerous. Read and follow all instructions on the can. Use this at your own risk! I built this to use as a "fire extinguisher" effect for L3-G0, my full size Lego R2-D2. It's intended as a mount to hold the can vertically, nozzle down, so it needs bolted into some sort of post. The servo then pulls the trigger and mist sprays out. For more about my Lego R2D2, check out L3-G0's blog or youtube channel. https://youtu.be/PmXUBGq_uiU shows L3-G0, but I don't have good video of him spraying his mist

WARNING: This project is just informational, use at your own risk! The canned air is nasty cold, as in can give you frostbite. I'm not responsible if it blows up in your face. Don't use it indoors. Keep it pointed away from you and away from your hands, people, etc. Adults only! READ and FOLLOW all the warnings on the can. Plan what to do if it breaks off the top when you're assembling or using it! This spray holder is designed to hold a thing of "canned air", like to spray off computer keyboards. The can tops differ, so you may need to tweak stuff a bit. It's in two parts (now 3) so that it doesn't need a lot of supports, but then it needs bolted together. The current holes are just big enough for #8 screws I think. I used a "door lock actuator" from amazon. $5-$15 depending on how you order it. My screws are just big enough that they thread themselves into the holes in the actuator, so I don't need long screws. I included several files, one is complete, but realistically it needs printed in 2 parts. Figure out if the smaller cover part needs the mount to be straight or rotated for your application. A) Get your actuator
B) Get your spray can, one without bitterant might be good if you can find it.
C) Figure out if your can is going to fit in the model.
  • Mine was 66mm in diameter, I gave it a little padding
  • Check the length too.
  • Check the nozzle shape
  • Check the mounting hole distance for the actuator.
    D) Adjust the model appropriately
    E) Print out the two halves.
    • For the top figure out if you need the offset mount or not.
      F) Mount the "bottom" to wherever it goes.
      G) Attach the actuator to the "top"
      H) Drill a hole in the trigger of the can (use care, it can be nasty, remove the trigger from can for this step if you can)
      I) Put the can in the bottom
      J) Attach the top to the bottom.
      K) Attach a string or something between the actuator and the trigger. My hole was small enough that the friction for the zip tie was enough I didn't even have to tie it!
    • Additionally I included a block, which provides both a slot to mount it on/off easily, and provided me with 1/2 inch of space I needed because my first attempt was too short. That may or may not be useful to you. Be careful attaching the trigger/actuator & measure the distance when the actuator is completely tight. First time I did it, the cord was too short and it snapped the lid right off. the trigger probably needs to move far less than the actuator. WARNING: Use caution. Read and follow all the warnings on the can.
